ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Broader familiarity with the topic & with work in molecular evolution at Yale
Seminar courses inherently bring in a lot of interesting work. Sheer exposure in this seminar was good.
I gained a broad understanding of the field, and got to discuss new research with professors from around the country as well as from Yale.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I thought it was great. Might be nice to expand the time to 1.5 hr, or to change instructions for the lecturers so that there is more time for discussion/interaction

It is a seminar course--the engagement was always going to be 'low'. But the speakers were well selected. The topic strayed a bit from 'molecular evolution' at times, but only in service of being interesting or bringing interesting people in.

For students taking this class for credit, it would be helpful to assign a paper to be read before seminar. It would help us to think about the research ahead of time and ask more thoughtful questions in discussions.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This was a great course that was singularly focused on exposing us to current work in the field.
Yes; the exposure to the faculty brought in from Yale and beyond is well worth the 9am course time.
